review_title: Mostly wonderful people, but uni leadership short sighted, political and bureaucratic
job_title: Associate Director in San Marcos, TX
pros:
Mostly great colleagues and people (staff, faculty and students) trying to foster learning make the world a better place in their disciplines. Staff and students within a research center created a good work culture. As long as we kept our heads down so as not to attract attention from leadership, it was awesome.

It was because of center culture that I stayed for a decade plus.
cons:
University Leadership bent to politics, created unnecessary bureaucracy in service to bureaucracy instead of to students and faculty/staff, no commitment to service in spite of the lip service to San Marcos or central TX community, punitive, stifled innovation, etc.

The university president was the source of most these horrible dynamics. But inner circle who she hand selected (and those reporting to them) equally to blame.
Over years in her quest to reach R1 status, president and other leaders undervalued Staff, especially when bringing $$$ to support service, faculty and students that didn’t fit the mold/add to the R1 numbers.

The university that used to be so focused on student learning learning is long gone.

Maybe the next president will make it better someday, but doubt it will be immediate.

This review written several years after I left but I still collaborate with colleagues, faculty and students in the department and center, and am involved with the university in various ways. My review as of this writing is still relevant.

job_title: Senior Lecturer in San Marcos, TX
pros: The University as a whole embraces diversity and is very inclusive. There is so much happening on campus at any one time. It's an intellectually and culturally stimulating atmosphere in terms of events and lectures. There are myriad of great people who care about the common mission and are engaged in ensuring student success at all levels. As an adjunct, there is a lot of freedom. As a Senior Lecturer there's twice the money.
cons:
The Academic, political culture is stuck. The tiered system leads to bullying and abuses of power. There is little security and morale suffers. Only tenured faculty have true Academic freedom. The disparity of work and pay is huge. Adjuncts are overused and paid very little for equivalent work.
Senior lecturers are asked to take on almost as much service, significant scholarly work, and equal course loads as Tenured and TT faculty, but are paid tens of thousands less. The promise of a 3 year contract is a total myth. The contract, by policy, is renewed every year pending a positive review, need, and funding. The hiring and firing process can be very ambiguous with fear of reprisals and bullying dictating relationships.

review_title: Too many staff members resistant to change and newer technology.
job_title: Supervisory Staff Member in San Marcos, TX
pros: The insurance is good, and the campus is very pretty.  The university also encourages being healthy and allows time each day for staff members to use for exercise.
cons: Many staff members have been with the university for long periods of time and are both resistant to technology and changes needed to keep a business running and spur productivity.  Younger staff members are often treated poorly, and new ideas or ways to improve productivity through technology are often ignored, specifically in departments with little student involvement (especially in the university administration departments).  Younger employees are treated as if they are threats to more seasoned employees in some offices, which creates tension and discord in the office.  Because of these and many additional issues, the younger employee turnover rate is higher.

job_title: Student Worker in San Marcos, TX
pros: Nice work environment and understanding management

job_title: Academic Coach in San Marcos, TX
pros: Most students are a joy to work with and you get a lot of administrative skills, presentation skills, and leadership experience. Though skating by I am able to make my rent and bills. They do require professional development seminars for all coaches which is helpful.
cons: Management micro-manages, for the large work load we have we are still one of the lowest paid GAs, and unlike other jobs (GAs included) on campus we do not have permission to do homework once our tasks for the day are finished (or risk being fired immediately). As we have been reminded by management, they do not have to go through a chain of punishments to fire (as in they are not obligated to give a verbal warning, write up, or intervention before firing).

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in San Marcos, TX
pros: Flexible scheduling, two week Christmas break in addition to vacation.  Co-workers were mostly awesome and hardworking.  Working with students was a joy.
cons: Per the President, there is not a career path for staff at Texas State as they are considered disposable.  Staff salaries are low and capped so pay adjustments are not allowed once the cap is reached.  Due to a gross discriminate class culture, many staff members are treated as second class citizens with few rights.  Most of the academic offices are helmed by untrained, inexperienced faculty as Chairs, Deans and Directors who use their staff as scapegoats for their mistakes which can lead to dismissal, censure and/or lost raises.  Inappropriate relationships with staff are commonplace.  Many great administrative staff workers have left for other colleges due to the culture at Texas State.  Benefits and health insurance have also been slashed.

review_title: Academically satisfying and supportive, but the bureaucracy and poor communication causes too much frustration.
job_title: in San Marcos, TX
pros: The university is generally supportive in giving practical experience for academics and students. Schedules can be flexible and the research environment is encouraging.
cons: There is very poor communication and too many clerical errors.  Mistakes over funding or errors in databases and registration systems can take several months to fix, if they're ever fixed at all.  There were several times where I had to go between offices and talk to office staff in different departments to get a payroll mistake or registration error fixed.  For one instance of getting funding, I filed paperwork in the beginning of the Fall semester.  The paperwork was lost (without notifying me of the mistake), so I re-filed in January when I noticed the funds weren't going through.  It is now May, and I am still sending paperwork in to get reimbursement.  In my experience, this is typical of Texas State.  A lot of the technology is also insufficient or outdated.  E.g., 170 mb for e-mail, including sent,drafts, and trash.

review_title: Texas State University Student Health Center
job_title: Prescription Assistance Advocate in San Marcos, TX
pros: I worked as a student at the Texas State University Student Health Center and really enjoyed my time there. The people were generally fun and it allowed me to start my career in healthcare administration earlier than most. Obviously, working with my school schedule was a big plus.
cons: Students are only allowed to work 25 hours during semesters they are taking classes. I was allowed to work 40 hours per week during the summers when I took classes at junior colleges. The pay for students was embarrassing and nearly disgusting while I was there. I had more responsibility than many full time staff members and made minimum wage just because I was a student. I've heard they've improved on this now.

job_title: Technology Resources in San Marcos, TX
pros: They have a relaxed atmosphere and a great campus; Texas has no prettier campus.  The people are mostly great.  There is a river nearby if you just have to tube during lunch.
cons: Benefits and pay are relatively dismal.  The tools and technology are fairly outdated.  The gym is not free for employee use (because of the excuse that it is paid for by student fees).  You have to pay for parking on the campus.  And, finally, they are constantly asking you to donate to various programs run by the University (with mild political pressure); basically asking you to pay them for paying you.

review_title: Good perks, fun work, great people, time suck.
job_title: Resident Assistant in San Marcos, TX
pros: The compensation is pretty hard to argue with.  Free dorm housing, free meal plan, and an allowance.  The allowance is small, but after your first semester as an RA you can get a job off campus.  You also get to work with many great people, the RA social network is huge.
cons: Depending on which dorm you work in, you can be working quite a bit outside of your scheduled desk hours and responsibilities.  Many times the Residence Directors will just pile on the work without much notice, but this of course varies by Residence Director.  It's also easy to just get absorbed with the dorm, spending all your time there.  Make sure to cultivate activities outside of the job.

job_title: Cataloger in Austin, TX
pros: Great community. Very flexible when it comes to vacation and sick time, at least in my position since I'm not at a service point. Awesome benefits. One of my favorite things is their wellness program in which you get 30 minutes every day to do a wellness activity. They really take your physical and mental health seriously and try hard to make you happy in your position. Also a great place to work while trying to continue your education. The university is growing very quickly and coming out with a lot of up and coming designs for universities so it's a great place to start a  career.
cons: It's a state job so there's a lot of bureaucratic policies that tend to make certain things difficult. Also budgets are at the mercy of state education cuts, which can have an impact on merit raises.

cons:
Distance to campus when living in Austin or San Antonio is not the best. Sometimes it feels isolating and hard to stick around when you know you have the drive ahead. The great community aspect you feel on campus does not follow you home.

It would also be great to be compensated in a way that made teaching feel worth it. Although I do enjoy the job, I know it's time to make a change since the pay is simply not enough, especially since going for tenure is not of interest to me.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in San Marcos, TX
pros: Flexible schedule, relatively ease in getting hired, supervisors who understand you are also working on your grad degree, nice culture with caring employees.  You are also eligible for health insurance, and the university picks up part of the cost.
cons: Pay is not very much for the amount of work. GAs are usually hired for 20 hours per week, but the hours go much higher at times if you are teaching courses or assigned classes with lots of grading. Graduate assistants who want to be hired after graduation often feel frustrated by the lack of opportunity or slowness in making hiring decisions (often made right before the semester begins).

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Marcos, TX
pros: Excellent benefits program with a nice campus. Found frequent opportunities to stretch my legs and make meaningful accomplishments. Does not make unnecessary demands on their staff's time.
cons: The difficulties with working in Higher Education are all present. Excessive bureaucratic overhead, politically charged environment, lack of clear communication between largely separate departments. Has a single minded focus on enrollment numbers in the same way that a company may have a single minded focus on marketing -- that is to say that it is to the exclusion of the actual quality of their product.

job_title: Doctoral Instructional Assistant in San Marcos, TX
pros: I have been working at Texas State University for like 3 years. It has a great working environment. People are very nice and they are mostly local people around. If you live in San Marcos, transportation is pretty convenient. I love this place!
cons: Even though it is a growing state university there are still not enough research opportunities for graduate students. In addition, the population of the school just keeps growing and growing so I am wondering how they are gonna fit that much students in the campus in the coming years!

review_title: Love the work; don't love the pay.
job_title: ADjunct Instrctor in San Marcos, TX
pros: Free to develop your own teaching approaches within reason; department administration is accessible and supportive; diverse student population; easy commute.

review_title: Part time work in a lab
job_title: Lab Assistant in San Marcos, TX
pros: It was relatively laid back and the hours were very flexible. I could even work at home as long as I was making progress with my work. There was a lot of freedom and decisions I could make on my own. The people in charge were very reasonable and were around when they needed to be.
cons: It took a long time to be entered into the payroll system. This may have been a problem with the particular department or funding issues. Some aspects of my job felt like they weren't necessarily my responsibility.

job_title: Student Worker in San Marcos, TX

review_title: Great Experience, but don't do it with a heavy course load
job_title: Resident Assistant in San Marcos, TX

cons: The experience was great.  Dealing with the DHRL redtape was frustrating they just want to much paperwork.  They also drag you to a bunch of unneccesary meetings and functions.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in San Marcos, TX

Excessive workload on her meant that I got very little attention and had to redo work that did not meet her unstated objectives. Periods of weeks would pass without any feedback, leading to plenty of unproductive working time.

review_title: Texas State University, Office of Veterans Affairs
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in San Marcos, TX

job_title: Supplemental Instruction Leader in San Marcos, TX

review_title: Human Resources Information System Analyst job
job_title: Human Resources Information Systems Analyst in San Marcos, TX

cons: Just like a lot of organizations, it's slow to change.  Also promotion/lateral movements through out the university is also slow sometimes.  A lot of focus is on faculty, so staff sometimes get put on the back burner.

review_title: My time at Texas State was rewarding and satisfying/
job_title: Grant Specialist in San Marcos, TX

cons: the large bureaucracy of a University setting can squash innovation, take forever to cut through red tape, and retain those employees that are less than satisfied with their career (leading to some grumpy people that don't get terminated).

job_title: Rock Wall Instructor in San Marcos, TX
pros: Texas State University is very flexible with student hours. The job is super chill, and you have a chance to meet tons of people. Fun and professional at the same time. And you get pro deals which allows you to get top quality outdoor gear for wholesale prices.
cons: Its hard to get a lot of hours. The pay is minimum wage or just above. The meetings are always on weekends so sometimes it is hard to get home to visit family. Sometimes the rock wall gets slow and boring.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Marcos, TX
pros:
In general, Texas State University is a great place to work. The benefits are excellent; healthcare is covered, they have tuition reimbursement, employees are automatically included in the Teacher Retirement system, there are lots of free training opportunities, and discounts available for certain retailers. Everyone who works here has a sense of absolute job security, no one ever seems to get fired or laid off. The campus generally has a very pleasant atmosphere, there are decent food options on campus, and plenty of great food choices just off campus. It can also be really nice to work along side students, they have so much energy and they can help to prevent you from getting too out of touch as you grow older.

In my particular office - and this can vary greatly depending on which office you work in - we all have a good amount of autonomy. There is a very amicable dynamic between my coworkers, we all have easy access to food and coffee throughout the day, no one ever seems too miserable.
cons: Change is slow at such a large, public institution. The opportunities for advancing your career are rare to the extent of being non-existent for most employees. If there is a certain policy that doesn't work, or a coworker who doesn't do their part, or something else that seems like it should change, you will have to learn to live with it because almost nothing ever changes. The pay for just about every job title is noticeably lower than what it would be in the private sector, and there are no periodic opportunities for pay raises, just a cost-of-living increase that adds about 2% to your paycheck each year if you have been performing well enough at your job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Marcos, TX
pros: State benefits are a huge plus for sometimes slightly lower salaries than in the private sector.  While some departments have internal issues, most of the employees I interact with are positive and enthusiastic about the work they do.  The students are great to work with, and overall, I am completely happy with my situation.
cons: As mentioned, some salaries are lower than the private sector....but, add in the benefits, such as three weeks of paid leave (spring break - one week, and two weeks at Christmas), plus 8 vacation hours a month, it becomes a better situation.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Marcos, TX
pros: very flexible schedule. The professors are very knowledgeable and work with you if you need extra time for grading or turning in work.
cons:
The job can be monotonous. There will be those students who will test your last nerve and will try to find a way to pass even though they mathematically are destined to fail the course.  
Growing student body....

review_title: I had a great experience working in the bookstore.
job_title: Textbook Clerk in San Marcos, TX
pros:
Training period was limited--mostly the managers would just show you around and show you how to use the system once or twice and then leave you to figure it out on your own; of course, you could ask questions if you were stuck.
Compensation for a student worker is $7.25/hr (minimum wage) which is not necessarily ideal in the career world, but as a full-time student, it's more than ideal.
Time off was as requested, so long as you wrote it in the request off book at least 2 weeks ahead of time. This is still up to the discretion of the manager you're working under.
cons:
The only cons really were the minimum wage aspect of the job, but again, if you're a full-time or even part-time college student, minimum wage is to be expected and they work around your class schedule. Personal growth is not difficult to achieve here, although sometimes you do feel as though you're very replaceable, and you more or less are, in fact, replaceable. But if you do a good job, they won't feel the need.
other downside is that it came with no benefits whatsoever aside from having a discount after 90 days of employment. 
If you don't ride the texas state shuttle, you must pay to park and this Is expensive. $3 for every 2 hours. 
Office culture, however, is outstanding. You work in a very educational-inclined setting and you get to know each of the classes for each of the departments intimately by working with their assigned textbooks.

review_title: Student Billing Assistant - Student Health Center

job_title: Graduate Instructional Assistant in San Marcos, TX

Also, the facilities are rather messy as if no custodial staff and paint peels from the wall with lots of other interior infrastructure problems.  The university has plenty of money, so a clean, well-maintained  building is not too much of a burden and should be done more often.  The faculty members are very busy.
